title: How I Use Essential Oils and Psoriasis

content: Essential oils have been used for a variety of things since humans existed. History shows essential oils being used in everything including forms of worship, beauty treatments, physical uses, psychological treatments, aromatherapy, baths, and much more.

Essential oils come from different parts of a plant or tree including the bark, fruit, flowers, leaves, petals, roots, resins, seeds, needles, and twigs. There are many methods of extracting the oils, and it’s best if they’re diluted before you use them. I also like to make sure I find pure essential oils and none that have been blended with other ingredients.

These oils have so many properties attached to them depending on which one. Essential oils may be antiviral, antibacterial, antifungal, antiseptic, anti-inflammatory, antineuralgic, antirheumatic, antispasmodic, antivenomous, antitoxic, antidepressant, digestive, expectorant, sedative, nervine, and a host of other beneficial medicinal and therapeutic properties.

There are many methods of receiving the benefits of oils externally such as compresses, body oils, and baths; inhaling methods include either directly from the bottle or dropping into your hand -- which I often do when congested -- diffusers, room sprays, and other environmental methods. It’s important to note that you should research oils before you use them, especially if you’re dealing with other health conditions, as we all respond differently to any type of remedy or treatment.

content: When it comes to psoriasis, there are essential oils that may benefit the skin and scalp, or manage stress to aid with the relief of flares. Let's go into detail about a few oils I’ve researched and may or may not have used yet that could possibly help you with psoriasis.
Frankincense (anti-inflammatory, pain relief, stimulates immune system, antiseptic)

This is also known as olibanum and was used often in religious practices. History shows it has been used as an insect repellent, perfume, for pain relief, and on the chest for respiratory relief. It’s been added to skin care routines as well as wounds, boils, and ulcers.
This oil is great for wounds, balances sebum production, and may assist with bleeding, acne, eczema, and dermatitis. Its analgesic properties may assist with nerve pain.

sections.heading: Lavender
content: Lavender is one of the top-selling essential oils because of its many uses and benefits. It may assist with joints and muscles, which may be helpful for many people with psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis. It has a host of benefits for the skin. It is also a very calming essential oil and may help with anxiety and sleep. Lavender is one of my favorite herbs and I use it quite often in herbal tea, in my diffuser at night before bed, and even mop my floors with it.

sections.heading: Tea tree
content: This powerful oil is a must-have in the home! It’s found in so many products ranging from household items to skin care. It’s great for assisting with viral, bacterial, and fungal infections. It has been used to aid in relieving respiratory-related concerns. Many skin, hair, and oral products have tea tree oil as a component. It’s important to note that this is definitely one you’d want to look into how to dilute with a carrier oil to prevent irritation. I have used shampoos and face products with tea tree. When I notice nail psoriasis forming, I mix aloe and tea tree to help control the flare and I notice a difference.
Other essential oils that I’ve come across in research that have been said to be beneficial for psoriasis include:

I’ve used many essential oils when doing household chores such as laundry and cleaning. I’ve used it with carrier oils on my skin. I love essential oils in my diffuser that acts as a humidifier as well. Please take some time to research essential oils, their benefits, and consider giving them a try. Talk to a provider if you need professional guidance.
